data.title: Interesting little place
data.text:
Potager is really interesting. You never know what's going to be served, and you pay what you like. They always have some sort of quiche, and usually have plenty of gluten free options for people. There's often live music, and if you can find room, the service is cheerful and prompt. You essentially get in line and they serve up whatever they've got.  They always also have some sort of dessert. 
The food is made from locally sourced product, and they often grow their own veggies.

data.title: Lunch at Potager
data.text: Disappointed.  Very limited menu with only quiche and green salad.  The quiche was over done.  I had a pear tart for dessert.  The serving was small and overpriced.  I don't plan to go back.

data.title: Oh, Potager, Where Have You Gone?
data.text: This restaurant is no longer open for business. The portions were small and you were encouraged to 'donate' money for the food. Guess this didn't work out very well...

data.title: Always a great meal!
data.text: While you never know what you'll get when you go here, you do know it will be good and they will have something that you'll love.

data.title: Early dinner
data.text:
The four of us (friends) found Potager charming. Three of us ordered the "little bit of everything" which was more than enough food. Each dish was nicely prepared with healthy ingredients. The pay what you want concept is unusual here in TX. There is a very small staff who were all cordial. 
The restaurant is moving nearby in the near future. Maybe then they will have handicapped access. One of my ladies is on a cane and had difficulty with the tall steps. 

P

data.title: Lunch with a friend!
data.text: Have eaten there a few times. Food very good but... saw something that I should not repeat!  Very dirty and unhealthy.  Brought it to the attention of the chef and he shrugged and walked away... We looked around and saw other areas of health concerns so we walked out immediately.  Very disappointed!!

data.title: Very European ambiance; comfortable with a folksy feeling.
data.text:
My friend and I arrived fairly early for lunch, so there was plenty of food. Everything looked delicious, but both of us ended up with a vegetable quiche, kale with macaroni and cheese and  a salmon salad. The portions were, opposed to most American res-taurants, small. We managed to eat everything on our plate and then had a slice of  applepie. 
The quiche was a little bland, but both the mac and cheese and salmon salad were well seasoned. The applepie was the best I've had in a long time.
When it was time to pay for the meal, I felt very ambivalent. Suggested amount was $15.00 for alittle bit and $20.00 for a little bit more. I put &30.00 inthe watering can and wonder if that was enough.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this restaurant, mainly for its comfortble setting. You do not feel hurried as is sometimes the case in popular places.

data.title: What an interesting concept. Fresh food.  Local.  Pay what you want.
data.text:
Not much to look at from outside. But don't judge a book by its cover.

You choose the price, they don't even like to make too much of a suggestion.  French food, local produce, whatever is available on that day.  They may not know until they begin to cook it.  Portions are small, as they ask you to make sure to eat whatever you take.  But repeated trips for seconds are allowed.  Small, intimate, not an overwhelmingly "romantic" place. But the food.  Just right, on so many levels.  We accidentally stumbled in, but will be back.  

By the way, just because it's name your price, doesn't mean that it's cheap.  We paid $50 for a terrific meal for the two of us, with as much as we wanted to eat.

data.title: Unique dinning experience well worth your time
data.text: This is a fantastic small restaurant. The entire dinning experience is friendly relaxed and always delicious. You feel like you are just having lunch at a friends' house. Their tossed salad is simply the best! They use an honor system for paying - you pay what you think it is worth and let me tell you it is worth it! WE love going there for lunch. They even have wine tasting evening now. Give it a try, its worth you time and your taste buds will thank you.

data.title: Menu of the Day - You Choose the Price
data.text: Potager is a "name your own price" café. The food is based on what is in season. You are asked to start with a little, and you can always come back for more. The management strives to limit wasted food. We've always enjoyed the fare. Be advised that it can get crowded, and the place is small. Going back for seconds can be a challenge. A sign lists suggested prices for the food, and some of the prices can be a little high.  Even though you decide the price, don't expect to pay fast food prices.  If you do, then you obviously missed the whole concept of supporting the local farmer.

data.title: Superb Food
data.text: Chose this restaurant for lunch randomly out of a brochure given to us at an art exhibit. Cuisine is based on organic availability and is prepared to please the palate. The furnishings are mismatched/recycled which lends well to the friendly, casual cafe setting with lively conversation with the staff about the food and philosophy of the restaurant.  Looking forward to going again.

data.title: Favorite casual cafe in Arlington-delicious!!
data.text: This funky and family friendly organic cafe has become my absolutely favorite place for a delicious and nutritious lunch.    Never had a bad dish.   All fresh, inventive and amazing.   Super friendly staff.    It's a 60's decor,  with a 2015 healthy food focus.   You pay what you feel your meal was worth in the garden watering can (there is a list of recommended contributions).    Go early, and bring cash.    They run out of the good stuff by around 130 during lunch,  never stopped in for dinner but am certain it would be fabulous!

data.title: Casual, hippie style cafe
data.text:
The cafe is in a standalone building on the edge of a small, old shopping plaza. It is filled with mis-matched second (or third-) hand furnishings and tableware. The short menu changes daily and is written on a chalk board. On our visit there was a salad, a soup, one entree, maybe 5 sides, and a dessert. You can order a small, medium, or large serving or whatever you want, or a tasting of everything.
You pay whatever you think it's worth, putting the cash (only) in an envelope. There is a recommended price list.
The soup and salad I had was wonderful! The side vegetable was overcooked for my taste, probably because it's cooked in advance and hangs around... He had a beef and lamb lasagna with very tasty flavor, but again, well done noodles.
The staff were very pleasant.

data.title: A true farm to table experience
data.text: We enjoyed everything..the ambience..eclectic decor..warm welcome by Cynthia..the proprietor and especially the delicious meal returned the next evening!

data.title: Not Quite Sure About This Place
data.text: The electricity went out when we were there and we did not get to eat. It is a "quaint" place and the staff was nice and apologizing about the electricity going out. I would go back and give them another chance and see what I think when there are no complications.

data.title: Very Nice Good Food
data.text: I was quite pleased to tumble on Potager Cafe. The food was excellent and knowing it is clean food made it that much better. At home we are all about the local and organic food; it is hard to find a place to eat out at that you can find these types of foods. My wife and went and tried everything and everything was good. I am sure we will be back. I wished there was a more structured pricing. This is the first time we have seen this pay what you wish thing. The french onion casserole was amazing as was everything else but we have never had that before.

data.title: Take your chances
data.text: This is a difficult review to write because I have eaten at the Potager several times and the food ranges from very good to very bad.  The concept is good - a limited menu of healthy, locally grown foods.  You can bring your own beverage and then pay what you feel the meal was worth.  The menu varies but usually there is a selection of two mains, at least two vegetables, a quiche, salad, soup, french bread and a dessert.  However, the taste and quality are hit or miss depending...

data.title: unexpectedly sweet
data.text:
I never leave hungry. Even if the menu seems unappealing, I give each item a whirl, and I've not ever been disappointed. I like a lot of salad and a sliver of quiche (which invariably becomes more salad and another sliver) 
I buy local and organic for myself, and it does me good to eat that way when I go out. Make sure and have a fruit thing for desert...you won't be sorry

data.title: Good food, but quirky
data.text: This is an interesting restaurant that is owned by a local couple, and has "pay what you think its worth" business concept. Each day they prepare a handful of dishes, which are always made using fresh, organic foods, and customers are free to serve themselves as little or as much as they please. After you are done eating, you can choose to pay whatever you thought the food was worth. I've been to that restaurant several times, and have never once not had great food there. That said, the service tends to be a bit inconsistent, and is at times downright rude. I've even been hassled by the owner (!) about leaving a few bites of leftovers on my plate, which was also the last time that I was there. Its really a decent place to eat at, but I wish that the owners had a better grasp of human communication and customer service.

data.title: What a unique experience
data.text: This place offers such a fun and different dining experience. Relaxed and welcoming. Loved chatting with the chef, got to taste everything on the menu. Get whatever you want, any size, and seconds! You can tell everything is fresh, the flavors are delicious!
